elements.content: A novel small-molecule compound of lithium iodine and 3-hydroxypropionitrile (HPN) has been successfully synthesized. Our combined experimental and theoretical studies indicated that LiIHPN is a Li-ion conductor, which is utterly different from the I–-anion conductor of LiI­(HPN)2 reported previously. Solid-state lithium–air batteries based on LiIHPN as the electrolyte exhibit a reversible discharge capacity of more than 2100 mAh g–1 with a cyclic performance over 10 cycles. Our findings provide a new way to design solid-state electrolytes toward high-performance lithium–air batteries.
elements.clean_text: A novel small-molecule compound of lithium iodine and 3-hydroxypropionitrile (HPN) has been successfully synthesized. Our combined experimental and theoretical studies indicated that LiIHPN is a Li-ion conductor, which is utterly different from the I--anion conductor of LiI(HPN)2 reported previously. Solid-state lithium-air batteries based on LiIHPN as the electrolyte exhibit a reversible discharge capacity of more than 2100 mAh g-1 with a cyclic performance over 10 cycles. Our findings provide a new way to design solid-state electrolytes toward high-performance lithium-air batteries.

elements.content: A new solid-state Li-ion conductor of LiIHPN has been successfully synthesized and was used for solid-state lithium−air batteries. Our results provide a new way to design solid-state electrolytes based on small organic and inorganic molecules toward high-performance lithium−air batteries.
elements.clean_text: A new solid-state Li-ion conductor of LiIHPN has been successfully synthesized and was used for solid-state lithium-air batteries. Our results provide a new way to design solid-state electrolytes based on small organic and inorganic molecules toward high-performance lithium-air batteries.

elements.content: Extensive attention has been focused on the development of solid electrolytes for all-solid-state high-energy lithium–air batteries because of their chemical/electrochemical stabilities and their nonpermeability of oxygen, carbon dioxide, and moisture in air. Considering the critical role of the solid-state electrolyte for Li-ion migration across the all-solid-state cell and the fact that the electrochemical reaction only takes place at a three-phase zone composed of oxygen gas/air electrode/solid electrolyte, the development of a high-quality interface between the solid electrolyte and air electrode is very important for high-performance all-solid-state lithium–air batteries. So far, two general classes of solid electrolytes for all-solid-state lithium–air batteries have been developed: inorganic ceramics and organic polymers. However, the ceramic electrolytes are hard solids, and the polymer electrolytes have chain entanglement and limited polydispersity. Therefore, their contact areas in the interface between solid electrolytes and air electrodes are much smaller than that between the liquid electrolyte and air electrode. Here, we report a new solid-state Li-ion conductor: lithium iodine (LiI) 3-hydroxypropionitrile (HPN), which is made up of organic and inorganic molecules. In this small-molecule electrolyte, Li ions are coordinated by discrete low-molecular-weight ligands such as a nitrile group (−CN), a hydroxyl group (−OH), and I atoms. Such a new solid electrolyte has the feature of high monodispersity and is expected to improve the performance of the solid-state rechargeable lithium–air battery because of good interfacial contact between the electrolyte and electrodes. Previous studies suggested that the small-molecule compound of LiI (HPN)2 is an I–-anion conductor. In this work, a novel class of Li+-cation conductor −LiIHPN is used in all-solid-state lithium–air batteries for the first time.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Extensive attention has been focused on the development of solid electrolytes for all-solid-state high-energy lithium-air batteries because of their chemical/electrochemical stabilities and their nonpermeability of oxygen, carbon dioxide, and moisture in air. Considering the critical role of the solid-state electrolyte for Li-ion migration across the all-solid-state cell and the fact that the electrochemical reaction only takes place at a three-phase zone composed of oxygen gas/air electrode/solid electrolyte, the development of a high-quality interface between the solid electrolyte and air electrode is very important for high-performance all-solid-state lithium-air batteries. So far, two general classes of solid electrolytes for all-solid-state lithium-air batteries have been developed: inorganic ceramics and organic polymers. However, the ceramic electrolytes are hard solids, and the polymer electrolytes have chain entanglement and limited polydispersity. Therefore, their contact areas in the interface between solid electrolytes and air electrodes are much smaller than that between the liquid electrolyte and air electrode. Here, we report a new solid-state Li-ion conductor: lithium iodine (LiI) 3-hydroxypropionitrile (HPN), which is made up of organic and inorganic molecules. In this small-molecule electrolyte, Li ions are coordinated by discrete low-molecular-weight ligands such as a nitrile group (-CN), a hydroxyl group (-OH), and I atoms. Such a new solid electrolyte has the feature of high monodispersity and is expected to improve the performance of the solid-state rechargeable lithium-air battery because of good interfacial contact between the electrolyte and electrodes. Previous studies suggested that the small-molecule compound of LiI (HPN)2 is an I--anion conductor. In this work, a novel class of Li+-cation conductor -LiIHPN is used in all-solid-state lithium-air batteries for the first time.

elements.content: LiI­(HPN)2 (single crystal synthesized by ref) and the highly pure LiI crystal (99.999% metal basis, Alfa Aesar) are prepared for the synthesis of single-crystal LiIHPN. LiI­(HPN)2 [5.5204(5) g, 20.001(2) mmol] and LiI [2.6672(5) g, 20.002(4) mmol] are mixed and stirred at 130 °C for 48 h into a homogeneous liquid in an argon-filled glovebox. The obtained LiIHPN liquid is stored in an oven at designed temperatures from 90 to 80 °C with decreasing steps of 0.5 °C day–1. After 3 weeks, single-crystal LiIHPN is obtained. The LiIHPN powder can simply be synthesized by annealing the mixture of LiI and LiI­(HPN)2 at 130 °C for 48 h.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental and Theoretical Methods

Synthesis

Preparation of Materials and Electrodes

LiI(HPN)2 (single crystal synthesized by ref) and the highly pure LiI crystal (99.999% metal basis, Alfa Aesar) are prepared for the synthesis of single-crystal LiIHPN. LiI(HPN)2 [5.5204(5) g, 20.001(2) mmol] and LiI [2.6672(5) g, 20.002(4) mmol] are mixed and stirred at 130 °C for 48 h into a homogeneous liquid in an argon-filled glovebox. The obtained LiIHPN liquid is stored in an oven at designed temperatures from 90 to 80 °C with decreasing steps of 0.5 °C day-1. After 3 weeks, single-crystal LiIHPN is obtained. The LiIHPN powder can simply be synthesized by annealing the mixture of LiI and LiI(HPN)2 at 130 °C for 48 h.

elements.content: 3D-G is prepared by a chemical-reduction-induced self-assembly method with hydroiodic acid (HI) as the reducing agent. In brief, 2.2 mL with a concentration of 46.5 mg mL–1 HI is added to the graphene oxide suspension (2.8 mL with a concentration of 3.0 mg mL–1) to form the mixture. Then, such a mixture is sonicated for 10 min and transferred to an oil bath at 90 °C for 12 h without stirring. The obtained black plate of graphene hydrogel is washed with ethanol and water in a Soxhlet extractor for 24 h to remove residual impurities, and then the wet hydrogels are freeze-dried for 2 days to obtain 3D-G.
elements.clean_text:
Three-Dimensional Graphene (3D-G)

3D-G is prepared by a chemical-reduction-induced self-assembly method with hydroiodic acid (HI) as the reducing agent. In brief, 2.2 mL with a concentration of 46.5 mg mL-1 HI is added to the graphene oxide suspension (2.8 mL with a concentration of 3.0 mg mL-1) to form the mixture. Then, such a mixture is sonicated for 10 min and transferred to an oil bath at 90 °C for 12 h without stirring. The obtained black plate of graphene hydrogel is washed with ethanol and water in a Soxhlet extractor for 24 h to remove residual impurities, and then the wet hydrogels are freeze-dried for 2 days to obtain 3D-G.

elements.content: After the finely ground powders of LiI and LiIHPN are heated with a molar ratio of 1:1 onto the surface of the 3D-G electrode (weight = 300 μg, diameter = 7 mm, and height = 1.2 mm) at 130 °C for 1 h, these mixture powders (total weight of 8 mg) are melted into the 3D-G electrode. The LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode can be easily formed after subsequent cooling to room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G Electrode

After the finely ground powders of LiI and LiIHPN are heated with a molar ratio of 1:1 onto the surface of the 3D-G electrode (weight = 300 μg, diameter = 7 mm, and height = 1.2 mm) at 130 °C for 1 h, these mixture powders (total weight of 8 mg) are melted into the 3D-G electrode. The LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode can be easily formed after subsequent cooling to room temperature.

elements.content: All-solid-state batteries of Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G are constructed as follows: a lithium plate (purity 99.999%) with a thickness of 0.5 mm (2.0 cm2) is directly used as an anode. Then, LiIHPN-LiI films (∼100 μm) are coated onto the lithiumplate. The LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode (diameter = 7 mm) is used as the air electrode. Nickel foam with a pore size of several hundred micrometers is used as the current collector. An all-solid-state Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G battery can be assembled by simply pressing one Li/LiIHPN-LiI plate onto the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode with the substrate of nickel foam in an argon-filled dry glovebox.
elements.clean_text:
Measurements

All-Solid-State Cell

All-solid-state batteries of Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G are constructed as follows: a lithium plate (purity 99.999%) with a thickness of 0.5 mm (2.0 cm2) is directly used as an anode. Then, LiIHPN-LiI films (~100 μm) are coated onto the lithiumplate. The LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode (diameter = 7 mm) is used as the air electrode. Nickel foam with a pore size of several hundred micrometers is used as the current collector. An all-solid-state Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G battery can be assembled by simply pressing one Li/LiIHPN-LiI plate onto the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode with the substrate of nickel foam in an argon-filled dry glovebox.

elements.content: A suitable single-crystal particle with dimensions of 0.250 × 0.200 × 0.130 mm3 is selected for X-ray diffraction (XRD). The crystal is sealed in a capillary to protect the sample from moisture. Diffraction data are collected on a Bruker AXS APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction data are collected over the full sphere and corrected for absorption. The structures are solved by direct methods using SHELXS and refined against F 2 on all data by full-matrix least squares with SHELXL-97. Details of the data collection and refinement are summarized in Tables S1–S4.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Test of LiIHPN

A suitable single-crystal particle with dimensions of 0.250 × 0.200 × 0.130 mm3 is selected for X-ray diffraction (XRD). The crystal is sealed in a capillary to protect the sample from moisture. Diffraction data are collected on a Bruker AXS APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction data are collected over the full sphere and corrected for absorption. The structures are solved by direct methods using SHELXS and refined against F 2 on all data by full-matrix least squares with SHELXL-97. Details of the data collection and refinement are summarized in Tables S1-S4.

elements.content: The ionic conductivities are measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Conductivity measurement is carried out using sandwiching with two carbon electrodes and one columnar electrode of LiI:LiIHPN, which are obtained by cold pressing iodine lithium (purity 99.999%) and LiIHPN with different molar ratios. Impedance data are obtained with a CHI660C electrochemical workstation (Chenhua, China) in the frequency range from 10 Hz to 100 kHz between 298 and 355 K. The conductivity of LiI:LiIHPN is calculated from by the known area and thickness as well as the examined resistance of C/LiI:LiIHPN/C by a CHI660A electrochemical workstation. σ = d / R b S where R b is the bulk resistance, d is the thickness of the LiIHPN electrolyte, and S is the area of the carbon electrode.
elements.clean_text:
Conductivity Measurement

The ionic conductivities are measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Conductivity measurement is carried out using sandwiching with two carbon electrodes and one columnar electrode of LiI:LiIHPN, which are obtained by cold pressing iodine lithium (purity 99.999%) and LiIHPN with different molar ratios. Impedance data are obtained with a CHI660C electrochemical workstation (Chenhua, China) in the frequency range from 10 Hz to 100 kHz between 298 and 355 K. The conductivity of LiI:LiIHPN is calculated from  by the known area and thickness as well as the examined resistance of C/LiI:LiIHPN/C by a CHI660A electrochemical workstation. 1    σ = d /   R   b   S   where R b is the bulk resistance, d is the thickness of the LiIHPN electrolyte, and S is the area of the carbon electrode.

elements.content: The electrolyte films of LiIHPN (diameter = 11.3 mm and thickness = 0.12 mm) are sandwiched between two carbon electrodes as blocking-type cells. The LiIHPN electrolyte films are sandwiched between two lithium-metal electrodes as nonblocking-type cells. The total amount of ion transference is calculated based on : t ion = 1 − I e / I t where I t and I e are the total and residual currents, respectively. The Li-ion transference numbers of LiIHPN electrolyte films are estimated using an alternating-current (ac) impedance combined with a direct-current (dc) polarization technique. The ac impedance and dc polarization curves of nonblocking-type cells (Li/LiIHPN/Li) are measured by a CHI660A electrochemical workstation. The step potential is 100 mV. The value of t Li+ is calculated from : t Li + = I s ( Δ V − R 0 I 0 ) / I 0 ( Δ V − R s I s ) where I 0 and I s are the initial and final currents, respectively, and R 0 and R s are the cell resistances before and after polarization, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Transference Number Measurement

The electrolyte films of LiIHPN (diameter = 11.3 mm and thickness = 0.12 mm) are sandwiched between two carbon electrodes as blocking-type cells. The LiIHPN electrolyte films are sandwiched between two lithium-metal electrodes as nonblocking-type cells. The total amount of ion transference is calculated based on : 2      t   ion   = 1 -   I   e   /   I   t     where I t and I e are the total and residual currents, respectively. The Li-ion transference numbers of LiIHPN electrolyte films are estimated using an alternating-current (ac) impedance combined with a direct-current (dc) polarization technique. The ac impedance and dc polarization curves of nonblocking-type cells (Li/LiIHPN/Li) are measured by a CHI660A electrochemical workstation. The step potential is 100 mV. The value of t Li+  is calculated from : 3      t    Li +    =  I s   ( Δ V -   R   0     I   0   )  /   I   0    ( Δ V -   R   s     I   s   )    where I 0 and I s are the initial and final currents, respectively, and R 0 and R s are the cell resistances before and after polarization, respectively.

elements.content: Charge/discharge measurements are performed at 355 K with a Land BT 1-40 battery test system. The current densities and capacities of the electrodes are calculated based on the total mass of 3D-G materials.
elements.clean_text:
Charge/Discharge Measurements

Charge/discharge measurements are performed at 355 K with a Land BT 1-40 battery test system. The current densities and capacities of the electrodes are calculated based on the total mass of 3D-G materials.

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Cambridge S-360) is employed to study the morphology of 3D-G and the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode. Powder XRD patterns are collected at Beamline X7B of the National Synchrotron Light Source at Brookhaven National Laboratory. The wavelength used is 0.3196 Å. The morphology of 3D-G are investigated by battery backscattered electron imaging and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra are captured using a FEI field-emission scanning electron microscope (Sirion XL) operated at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) measurements are carried out in a 200 kV side entry JEOL 2010 transmission electron microscope with an EDX analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Characterization

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Cambridge S-360) is employed to study the morphology of 3D-G and the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode. Powder XRD patterns are collected at Beamline X7B of the National Synchrotron Light Source at Brookhaven National Laboratory. The wavelength used is 0.3196 Å. The morphology of 3D-G are investigated by battery backscattered electron imaging and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra are captured using a FEI field-emission scanning electron microscope (Sirion XL) operated at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) measurements are carried out in a 200 kV side entry JEOL 2010 transmission electron microscope with an EDX analyzer.

elements.content: To understand the microscopic ion-transport mechanism in the LiI­(HPN) n (n = 0, 1, 2) system, we carry out first-principles calculations adopting the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof generalized-gradient-approximation and projector-augmented-wave pseudopotential, as implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package. Intermolecular forces of HPN are not negligible, so we choose the DFT-D2 method of Grimme in the LiIHPN calculation. We use a plane-wave cutoff energy of 520 eV and a 1 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack k-point grid with Gaussian smearing of 0.20 eV to relax the electronic energies and nuclear degrees of freedom. The calculations are performed in a monoclinic 8 formula unit (fu) LiIC3H5NO, and all internal parameters are fully relaxed with a force convergence criterion of less than 0.02 eV Å–1, while the lattice parameters are optimized with a total energy convergence within a 10–4 eV per unit cell. The densities of states are obtained with Γ-centered 2 × 5 × 2 meshes. The ion-hopping barriers are obtained using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CINEB) method with a total energy convergence within 10–4 eV per unit cell and a force convergence within 0.05 eV Å–1. By comparison, 4 fu face-centered-cubic LiI are calculated with a plane-wave cutoff energy of 230 eV and a 5 × 5 × 5 Monkhorst–Pack k-point grid based on the DFT method. A supercell consisting of 2 × 2 × 1 primitive unit cells for LiI is selected in our CINEB calculations. The convergence criteria are the same as those for LiIHPN. The lattice parameters of a unit cell of LiI, LiIHPN, and LiI­(HPN)2 before and after optimization and the computational band gaps are list in Table S1. The calculated average bond lengths for LiIHPN and LiI­(HPN)2 and the bond length for related inorganic compounds are listed in Table S3.
elements.clean_text:
Density Functional Theory (DFT) Calculations

To understand the microscopic ion-transport mechanism in the LiI(HPN) n  (n = 0, 1, 2) system, we carry out first-principles calculations adopting the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof generalized-gradient-approximation and projector-augmented-wave pseudopotential, as implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package. Intermolecular forces of HPN are not negligible, so we choose the DFT-D2 method of Grimme in the LiIHPN calculation. We use a plane-wave cutoff energy of 520 eV and a 1 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid with Gaussian smearing of 0.20 eV to relax the electronic energies and nuclear degrees of freedom. The calculations are performed in a monoclinic 8 formula unit (fu) LiIC3H5NO, and all internal parameters are fully relaxed with a force convergence criterion of less than 0.02 eV Å-1, while the lattice parameters are optimized with a total energy convergence within a 10-4 eV per unit cell. The densities of states are obtained with Γ-centered 2 × 5 × 2 meshes. The ion-hopping barriers are obtained using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CINEB) method with a total energy convergence within 10-4 eV per unit cell and a force convergence within 0.05 eV Å-1. By comparison, 4 fu face-centered-cubic LiI are calculated with a plane-wave cutoff energy of 230 eV and a 5 × 5 × 5 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid based on the DFT method. A supercell consisting of 2 × 2 × 1 primitive unit cells for LiI is selected in our CINEB calculations. The convergence criteria are the same as those for LiIHPN. The lattice parameters of a unit cell of LiI, LiIHPN, and LiI(HPN)2 before and after optimization and the computational band gaps are list in Table S1. The calculated average bond lengths for LiIHPN and LiI(HPN)2 and the bond length for related inorganic compounds are listed in Table S3.

elements.content: The crystal structure of LiI:HPN = 1:1 is shown in (1). According to single-crystal structure analysis (), the molecular formula of the compound is LiIC3H5NO (LiIHPN) and the molecular weight is 204.92. It belongs to the C2/c space group with the monoclinic parameters a = 15.750(5) Å, b = 5.5760(18) Å, c = 16.139(7) Å, and β = 117.405(3)°. There are eight molecules in a unit cell. One Li ion is coordinated with four atoms in the single-crystal structure of LiIHPN. For example, Li1 is coordinated with N1#1 of the nitrile group, O1 of the hydroxyl group, and two iodide atoms (I1 and I1#2). Two Li ions are connected via two HPN molecules to form a closed 12-membered ring. Two neighboring rings are connected via an iodide atom to form a three-dimentional net-like structure. The bond length of Li1–N1#1 is 1.982(2) Å, that of Li1–O1 is 1.904(7) Å, that of Li1–I1 is 2.742(7) Å, and that of Li1–I1#2 is 2.739(7) Å. It is known that the bond lengths of Li–O and Li–N in inorganic compounds are in the ranges of 1.9–2.1 and 1.94–2.3 Å, respectively. The above data indicate that strong chemical bonds between Li, O, and N atoms exist in LiIHPN. It should be noticed that each HPN molecule has two possible positions, which are shown as H1–O1–C1–C2–C3–N1 and H1–O1–C1′–C2′–C3–N1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The crystal structure of LiI:HPN = 1:1 is shown in (1). According to single-crystal structure analysis (), the molecular formula of the compound is LiIC3H5NO (LiIHPN) and the molecular weight is 204.92. It belongs to the C2/c space group with the monoclinic parameters a = 15.750(5) Å, b = 5.5760(18) Å, c = 16.139(7) Å, and β = 117.405(3)°. There are eight molecules in a unit cell. One Li ion is coordinated with four atoms in the single-crystal structure of LiIHPN. For example, Li1 is coordinated with N1#1 of the nitrile group, O1 of the hydroxyl group, and two iodide atoms (I1 and I1#2). Two Li ions are connected via two HPN molecules to form a closed 12-membered ring. Two neighboring rings are connected via an iodide atom to form a three-dimentional net-like structure. The bond length of Li1-N1#1 is 1.982(2) Å, that of Li1-O1 is 1.904(7) Å, that of Li1-I1 is 2.742(7) Å, and that of Li1-I1#2 is 2.739(7) Å. It is known that the bond lengths of Li-O and Li-N in inorganic compounds are in the ranges of 1.9-2.1 and 1.94-2.3 Å, respectively. The above data indicate that strong chemical bonds between Li, O, and N atoms exist in LiIHPN. It should be noticed that each HPN molecule has two possible positions, which are shown as H1-O1-C1-C2-C3-N1 and H1-O1-C1'-C2'-C3-N1.

The structures of LiIHPN along the a, b, and c axes are shown in (2), respectively. The hydrogen bond, C1′, and C2′ are omitted for clarity. It is observed that each Li ion is almost in the central site of the tetrahedron surrounded by four atoms, i.e., one N atom in the nitrile group (−CN), one O atom in the hydroxyl group (−OH), and two I atoms. Two sequent Li anions are connected via two organic molecules to form a closed 12-membered ring. Different from the iodide anion in LiI­(HPN)2, the iodide anion in LiIHPN is restrained by two Li ion and two hydrogen bonds of the hydroxyl groups. As shown in , the bond length of H1···I1 is 2.69(5) Å. Details of the other bond lengths, bond angles, and atomic coordinates for the single-crystal structure are listed in Tables S1 and S2.
elements.clean_text: The structures of LiIHPN along the a, b, and c axes are shown in (2), respectively. The hydrogen bond, C1', and C2' are omitted for clarity. It is observed that each Li ion is almost in the central site of the tetrahedron surrounded by four atoms, i.e., one N atom in the nitrile group (-CN), one O atom in the hydroxyl group (-OH), and two I atoms. Two sequent Li anions are connected via two organic molecules to form a closed 12-membered ring. Different from the iodide anion in LiI(HPN)2, the iodide anion in LiIHPN is restrained by two Li ion and two hydrogen bonds of the hydroxyl groups. As shown in , the bond length of H1⋅⋅⋅I1 is 2.69(5) Å. Details of the other bond lengths, bond angles, and atomic coordinates for the single-crystal structure are listed in Tables S1 and S2.

In order to figure out the ion-conductor type of single-crystal LiIHPN and the ion-transport mechanism in the LiIHPN crystal structure, we have calculated the ion-hopping barrier for LiIHPN and LiI by using the CINEB method, which can efficiently determine the pathway for structural changes and ion transport. Through rotation of the model of the crystal structure LiIHPN in Material Studio, we found the spaces around each Li and I ion are very open along three directions. The distance between the two nearest-neighboring Li or I ions in LiIHPN is 4.079 or 4.609 Å, and the ion radius of a Li or I ion is 0.76 or 2.2 Å, respectively. We calculated the ion-hopping barriers of LiIHPN by moving a Li or I ion to their nearest-neighboring sites, the ions of which had been removed beforehand to avoid blocking the way.

Through rotation of the model of the crystal structure LiIHPN in Material Studio, we found the spaces around each Li and I ion are very open along three directions. elements.content: The energy barriers for LiIHPN are illustrated in . The data from LiI are included for comparison. The energy barriers of the Li ions in LiI (0.39 eV) and LiIHPN (0.57 eV) are lower than those in the case of I (1.13 and 0.81 eV), which indicates that LiIHPN and LiI are Li-ion conductors. Meanwhile, the difference of the energy barriers between the Li and I ions in LiI (0.74 eV) is larger than that in LiIHPN (0.24 eV) but smaller than that in LiI­(HPN)2 (−7.66 eV). These results indicate that the ion-conductor type of LiIHPN is a Li ion, which is utterly different from LiI­(HPN)2 as an I-ion conductor. Apparently, the crystal structure change of synthesized LiIHPN after annealing of the mixture of LiI and LiI­(HPN)2 at 130 °C for 48 h results in different ion-conductor types from LiI­(HPN)2.

elements.content: The dependence of the ionic conductivity of LiIHPN on the temperature is shown in . The values from LiI­(HPN)2 and references are included for comparison. Both electrolytes of LiIHPN and LiI­(HPN)2 exhibit a typical Arrhenius behavior. Significantly, LiI­(HPN)2 is an I-ion conductor, while LiIHPN is a Li-ion conductor. Their ionic conductivities were about 1.8 × 10–6 and 2.3 × 10–8 S cm–1 at 25 °C, respectively. The experimental values of LiI­(HPN)2 are well consistent with the references. However, the data from LiIHPN synthesized in this work are utterly different from those in previous work, in which LiIHPN is synthesized by simply mixing LiI and LiI­(HPN)2 with a molar ratio of 1:1. Apparently, the crystal structure of synthesized LiIHPN changes after annealing of the mixture of LiI and LiI­(HPN)2 at 130 °C for 48 h.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the ionic conductivity of LiIHPN with the various LiI concentrations is shown in . All of the composite electrolytes exhibit a well-linear fit of an Arrhenius plot. Significantly, enhancement of the ionic conductivity of LiIHPN with the addition of LiI is found. The ionic conductivity at LiI/LiIHPN = 1 is 1.4 × 10–4 S cm–1 in 328 K and is over 2 orders of magnitude higher than that of pure LiIHPN (4.9 × 10–7 S cm–1). The highest conductivity of 1.8 × 10–3 S cm–1 for the electrolyte from LiI/LiIHPN = 1 can be achieved in 355 K. The increasing concentration of Li ions with the introduction of LiI into LiIHPN should also be responsible for enhancing the ionic conductivity. In addition, it is known that the boundary region in a composite material (as shown in Figure S1, a physical mixture of LiIHPN with LiI is confirmed) is much larger than that in a single system, which makes the transport of lithium easily. These reasons are beneficial to enhancing the ionic conductivity with the addition of LiI into LiIHPN.

elements.content: In order to study the electrochemical window of LiIHPN, a linear sweep polarization is performed at 355 K. As shown in , a wide electrochemical window of at least 5.5 V for the solid LiIHPN electrolyte is achieved. Such a wide window can be used for lithium–air batteries. The current responses of Li/LiIHPN/Li and C/LiIHPN/C as a function of time during voltage stepping from 0 to 0.1 V are examined to clarify the ion-transference feature of LiIHPN, as shown in . When the potential is applied across C/LiIHPN/C, ionic and electronic conductions can be separated because Li ions are blocked by carbon contacts. The total (I t) and residual (I e) currents are 11.8 and 0.02 μA, respectively. The value of the total ionic-transference number evaluated from (in the section) is calculated to be 0.996, suggesting that charge transport in LiIHPN is ionic. The Li-ion-transference number (t Li+ ) has been evaluated by combining ac and dc techniques. The current evolution of Li/LiIHPN/Li with longer time is caused by the migration of Li ions in LiIHPN. The dc polarization curve of symmetric cells Li/LiI­(HPN)/Li indicates that the initial (I 0) and final (I s) currents are 3.49 and 3.33 μA, respectively. As shown in the inset of , the cell resistances before (R 0) and after (R s) polarization for Li/LiI­(HPN)/Li are 2314 and 2328 Ω, respectively. According to in the section, t Li+ is evaluated to be 0.96 for the LiIHPN electrolyte. These results strongly support that LiIHPN is a Li-ion conductor.

elements.content: Three-dimensional graphene (3D-G) materials were used for air electrodes because of their unique mechanical characteristics, excellent electrical conductivity, and large surface area. As shown in , the graphene electrode obtained by freeze-drying the graphene hydrogels exhibits similar 3D network structures composed of a large amount of interconnected macropores. Many ripples and wrinkles on the graphene electrode form the highly macroporous structure of the graphene, which enables small-molecule electrolytes to be readily infiltrated, leading to 3D-G network-based conducting composites. In order to investigate the composition and morphology of the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode, backscattered electron images of the 3D-G electrode after the powder mixture of LiIHPN and LiI melted into the 3D-G electrode are examined. The EDX results of the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode are shown in . It is clearly found that N, C, I, and O elements are highly dispersed into the surface of the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode. LiIHPN-LiI particles/clusters could closely anchor on 3D-G and have intimate contact with the 3D-G matrix. The LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G electrode offers a much larger contact area between 3D-G and the solid-state electrolyte, which reduces the inner resistance of the electrode, facilitates electron and ion transportation to/from active sites during the discharge/charge process, and therefore may help in improving the performance of lithium–air batteries.

elements.content: shows the galvanostatic cycling profiles of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient air at the current density of 67 mA g–1. In order to ensure a high value of the Coulombic efficiency, the charge capacity is limited to 2740 mAh g–1. The cell is discharged at a fixed voltage of 1.9 V to achieve a good cyclic performance. The open-circuit voltage (OCV) of the cell is about 2.8 V. The first and second discharge capacities of the cell are about 1470 and 2100 mAh g–1, respectively. These measurements can be carried out for up to 10 cycles. This performance is close to that of the previously reported all-solid-state lithium–air battery (1000 mAh g–1 and a cycle number of 10) but needs to be further improved. In order to further confirm the air electrode character, the charge/discharge performance of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient argon for comparison is carried out (the red curves in the first cycle). In ambient argon, the discharge curve is almost drop line and the initial discharge capacity is less than 30 mAh g–1, indicating that there is no Faraday process during the discharge process. The discharge curve of the cell is significantly different from that in ambient air, indicating that LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G in ambient air is an air cathode. In addition, it can be found that the discharge capacity of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient argon is much lower than the charge capacity, indicating the possibility of decomposition from the solid electrolyte. Decomposition of LiI from a physical mixture of the LiIHPN-LiI electrolyte (Figure S1) is electrochemically driven by graphene as an efficient catalyst.

elements.content: In order to further grasp the features of the air cathode, SEM and TEM images of the 3D-G electrode after discharge to 1.8 V are measured. As shown in a, many particles with sizes of about 150 nm are observed on the surface of the electrode at the discharged state. These particles are uniformly distributed in the 3D-G electrode and closely anchored on graphene. Because of the existence of the LiIHPN-LiI thin film (less than 50 nm) on the surface of graphene, the electrochemical reaction of O2 in air with Li ions is limited to a local space between LiIHPN and graphene films, resulting in coated nanoparticles of the products with LiIHPN. The composition of the discharged product is identified by TEM after the lithiated 3D-G electrodes are rinsed in acetone to eliminate LiIHPN. Two-dimensional lattices can be clearly seen in this image, as shown in b. After the d space is measured in two directions, they can be attributed to (200) of Li2O2. The SAED pattern in this phase, shown in the inset of b, exhibits some rings made up of discrete spots, indicating the nanosized polycrystalline nature of the discharged product. All d spacings derived from the SAED spectrum could be unambiguously indexed by the Li2O2 phase (JCPDS 73-1640; Li2O2).

elements.content: It should be noted that the OCV of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient air (2.8 V) is lower than the previously reported values of lithium–air batteries, which might be associated with the decomposed potential of LiI at 2.79 V. After the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell is allowed to stand in air, the OCV of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell will be larger than 2.8 V if the active sites on the air cathode are fully covered by O2 in air; this will result in the direct decomposition of LiI from LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G and the formation of I2 on the surface of the air electrode. It is reasonably assumed that I2 instead of O2 is covered on the surface of the air electrode at the primary state of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell. Thus, the electrochemical reaction mechanisms of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell at the air electrode side are proposed as follows:During discharging I 2 + 2 e − + 2 Li + → 2 LiI O 2 + 2 e − + 2 Li + → Li 2 O 2 During charging 6 LiI → 2 I 3 − + 6 Li + + 6 e − 2 I 3 − + 3 Li 2 O 2 → 6 LiI + 3 O 2 Li ions will react with I2 from decomposition of LiI on the air electrode to form LiI during the initial period of the discharge process and can be expressed by . After I2 at the surface of the air electrode is exhausted, O2 in air will be enriched on the air electrode instead of I2, and the discharge process proceeds with the electrochemical reaction of O2, as expressed by . This could be used to explain for the feature of the discharge curve, in which a shorter sloping voltage plateau from 2.7 to 2.5 V (less than 250 mAh g–1 and less than 10% of the total discharge capacity) and a sloping voltage plateau from 2.3 to 1.9 V are observed. They should correspond to discharge reactions of I2 and O2 on the air electrode with lithium, respectively. The discharge plateau from 2.3 to 1.9 V is lower than those of the previously reported lithium–air batteries. This may be due to passivation after the reduction reaction process at 2.7–2.5 V. A charge capacity of 2740 mAh g–1 is observed for the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient argon. The initial charge peak centered at 2.74 V versus Li corresponds to the electrochemical decomposition of LiI electrochemically driven by graphene as an efficient catalyst, as described as , which can be confirmed by Raman measurements (Figure S2). The charge potential versus Li+/Li is less than that in a recent report. The difference is mainly ascribed to the fact that the charge reaction of LiI occurs at a high temperature of 355 K in the present work instead of at room temperature in Liu’s work. The reverse charge process of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient air should mainly involve the electrochemistry of LiI () as the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient argon and the chemical reaction of Li2O2 with I3 – [supported by Raman data (Figure S2)], in which the oxidized product of I3 – will spontaneously react with Li2O2 formed after the discharge process to regenerate LiI and release O2 at the air electrode side (). Obviously, the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient air is a typical lithium–air battery with LiIHPN as the solid-state electrolyte and both LiI and graphene as catalysts.

The difference is mainly ascribed to the fact that the charge reaction of LiI occurs at a high temperature of 355 K in the present work instead of at room temperature in Liu's work. The reverse charge process of the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient air should mainly involve the electrochemistry of LiI () as the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient argon and the chemical reaction of Li2O2 with I3 - [supported by Raman data (Figure S2)], in which the oxidized product of I3 - will spontaneously react with Li2O2 formed after the discharge process to regenerate LiI and release O2 at the air electrode side (). Obviously, the Li/LiIHPN-LiI/LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cell in ambient air is a typical lithium-air battery with LiIHPN as the solid-state electrolyte and both LiI and graphene as catalysts.

elements.content: The chemistry of small-molecule compounds based on LiI and HPN is revealed, and manipulation of the ratio of LiI to HPN can lead to the design of different structural parameters and band energies of small-molecule compounds. Interestingly, LiIHPN is a Li-ion conductor, which is utterly different from the previously reported LiI­(HPN)2 as a I-ion conductor. Furthermore, all-solid-state lithium–air batteries could be achieved by using a perfect combination of the LiIHPN electrolyte and the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cathode. Our findings have demonstrated that a small-molecule solid-state electrolyte based on organic and inorganic molecules can be employed for the first time for high-performance lithium–air batteries.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The chemistry of small-molecule compounds based on LiI and HPN is revealed, and manipulation of the ratio of LiI to HPN can lead to the design of different structural parameters and band energies of small-molecule compounds. Interestingly, LiIHPN is a Li-ion conductor, which is utterly different from the previously reported LiI(HPN)2 as a I-ion conductor. Furthermore, all-solid-state lithium-air batteries could be achieved by using a perfect combination of the LiIHPN electrolyte and the LiIHPN-LiI@3D-G cathode. Our findings have demonstrated that a small-molecule solid-state electrolyte based on organic and inorganic molecules can be employed for the first time for high-performance lithium-air batteries.

cln_elements.content: 3D-G is prepared by a chemical-reduction-induced self-assembly method with hydroiodic acid (HI) as the reducing agent. In brief, 2.2 mL with a concentration of 46.5 mg mL–1 HI is added to the graphene oxide suspension (2.8 mL with a concentration of 3.0 mg mL–1) to form the mixture. Then, such a mixture is sonicated for 10 min and transferred to an oil bath at 90 °C for 12 h without stirring. The obtained black plate of graphene hydrogel is washed with ethanol and water in a Soxhlet extractor for 24 h to remove residual impurities, and then the wet hydrogels are freeze-dried for 2 days to obtain 3D-G.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Three-Dimensional Graphene (3D-G)

3D-G is prepared by a chemical-reduction-induced self-assembly method with hydroiodic acid (HI) as the reducing agent. In brief, 2.2 mL with a concentration of 46.5 mg mL-1 HI is added to the graphene oxide suspension (2.8 mL with a concentration of 3.0 mg mL-1) to form the mixture. Then, such a mixture is sonicated for 10 min and transferred to an oil bath at 90 °C for 12 h without stirring. The obtained black plate of graphene hydrogel is washed with ethanol and water in a Soxhlet extractor for 24 h to remove residual impurities, and then the wet hydrogels are freeze-dried for 2 days to obtain 3D-G.

cln_elements.content: A novel small-molecule compound of lithium iodine and 3-hydroxypropionitrile (HPN) has been successfully synthesized. Our combined experimental and theoretical studies indicated that LiIHPN is a Li-ion conductor, which is utterly different from the I–-anion conductor of LiI­(HPN)2 reported previously. Solid-state lithium–air batteries based on LiIHPN as the electrolyte exhibit a reversible discharge capacity of more than 2100 mAh g–1 with a cyclic performance over 10 cycles. Our findings provide a new way to design solid-state electrolytes toward high-performance lithium–air batteries.

Solid-state lithium-air batteries based on LiIHPN as the electrolyte exhibit a reversible discharge capacity of more than 2100 mAh g-1 with a cyclic performance over 10 cycles. Our findings provide a new way to design solid-state electrolytes toward high-performance lithium-air batteries.
